diagnoses.name: Chronic sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation and infection of the sinuses, leading to post-nasal drip, cough, and potentially contributing to oral pain from sinus pressure.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disease in which stomach acid irritates the food pipe lining, which can lead to post-nasal drip, cough, and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Oral thrush
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection in the mouth, causing oral pain and potentially complicating periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Periodontitis
diagnoses.description: Advanced stage of periodontal disease, causing gum inflammation, and potentially contributing to oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: Can cause periodontal disease, oral pain, episodic weakness, and make individuals more susceptible to infections, which could explain cough and post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord that can cause episodic weakness and may indirectly contribute to other symptoms through effects on health management.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Can cause periodontal disease, oral pain, and make individuals more susceptible to infections, which might account for cough and post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the mouth and eyes, potentially leading to periodontal disease and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing symptoms such as post-nasal drip and cough.

diagnoses.name: Respiratory tract infections
diagnoses.description: Infections that can cause cough, post-nasal drip, and may exacerbate symptoms like oral pain due to increased sinus pressure or secondary infections.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels. This condition can cause mouth ulcers, skin problems, genital sores, and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood, leading to easy bleeding and sometimes associated with thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Glanzmann Thrombasthenia
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic platelet disorder leading to impaired blood clotting, resulting in easy and often spontaneous bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can cause ulcers in the digestive tract and lead to symptoms outside the gastrointestinal system, including skin problems and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs, potentially leading to thrombocytosis and bleeding issues.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Neoplasm
diagnoses.description: A group of blood cancers that result in excess production of blood cells by the bone marrow. It can lead to thrombocytosis and is associated with a higher risk of bleeding and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a lack of vitamin C, leading to symptoms such as easy bleeding, especially from the gums (periodontal disease), and bruising.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels, resulting in spontaneous bleeding and possible skin flushing.

diagnoses.name: Primary Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow disorder causing an increase in the number of platelets, leading to a risk of clotting and bleeding problems.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where cancerous growths in the digestive system or lungs release hormones into the bloodstream, often leading to flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Anemia (various types, e.g., iron-deficiency anemia, anemia of chronic disease)
Graves' Disease with Thyroid Eye Disease (in rare cases presenting with hypothyroidism)
Thyroidectomy or radioiodine treatment leading to hypothyroidism

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially causing lymphadenopathy, liver enzyme abnormalities, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can cause lymphadenopathy, liver enzyme abnormalities, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenopathy and can also affect liver enzyme levels.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the liver, often due to viral infections, causing abnormal liver enzymes, and can be associated with hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs, including the liver and lymph nodes, potentially leading to abnormal liver enzymes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also cause lymphadenopathy and liver enzyme abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that weakens the immune system, can cause lymphadenopathy, and affect liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and organ damage, including liver enzyme abnormalities and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: A parasitic infection that can cause lymphadenopathy, and in rare cases, liver enzyme abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Drug hypersensitivity reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to medication that can cause hypersensitivity reactions, liver enzyme abnormalities, and in some cases, lymphadenopathy.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A demyelinating disease in which the insulating covers of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord are damaged.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Any intracranial tumor created by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself, the skull, the cranial nerves, the brain envelopes, or the pituitary and pineal gland.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.details: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. Over time, having too much sugar in your blood can cause damage to nerves and blood vessels, leading to a variety of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Can cause neurologic problems and muscle weakness in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, can cause weakness and tiredness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. It can include symptoms such as numbness and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to demyelination of nerve fibres, which can cause symptoms like numbness, weakness, and difficulty in speech (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain, causing symptoms similar to a stroke, such as paralysis, numbness, aphasia, and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include numbness or paralysis on one side of the body, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling. It can progress rapidly, requiring immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms depending on the tumor's location, such as seizures, numbness, speech difficulties (aphasia), and photophobia due to increased intracranial pressure.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological issues, including numbness, tingling in the hands and feet, difficulty maintaining balance, and cognitive disturbances like memory loss.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can lead to neurological complications such as facial palsy, neuropathy, and meningitis, causing symptoms such as numbness and difficulty in speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It can cause severe headaches, fever, confusion, photophobia, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, causing numbness, tingling, and pain in the hands and feet, and potentially affecting other parts of the body.

diagnoses: Conversion Disorder or Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease marked by muscular weakness without atrophy. It primarily affects voluntary muscles, especially those that control the eyes, mouth, throat, and limbs.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called an aura, including flashes of light, blind spots, and other vision changes or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, but typically lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation that damages the optic nerve, a bundle of nerve fibers that transmits visual information from your eye to your brain. Pain and temporary vision loss in one eye are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Its symptoms depend on the size, type, and location of the tumor.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and eventually death.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to neurological issues, including weakness, numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, difficulty walking, memory loss, and disorientation.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr virus, HIV)
Lupus with Central Nervous System Involvement
